name: Shortness of Breath
description: 72-year-old male presenting with progressive shortness of breath
learningObjectives: Take a thorough history from a vague historian
Recognize subtle clues pointing to the underlying diagnosis
Navigate complex decision-making with incomplete information
Balance competing risks in anticoagulation decisions

exam.heartSounds: S3 gallop, 2/6 systolic murmur at apex

naturalProgression.description: Without treatment, patient will continue to accumulate fluid and worsen

triggers.name: Patient Emotional Distress
triggers.message: Doctor... I'm scared. I can't breathe right and nobody's telling me what's wrong with me. Am I dying? My wife is worried sick out there and I don't know what to tell her. I just... I don't want to end up like my brother - he died in the hospital, you know. They kept poking and prodding him and he never came home.

decisionPoint.name: Empathy Response
decisionPoint.description: Patient is scared and needs emotional support
decisionPoint.teachingPoint: Patients who are scared need emotional validation before they can process medical information. Taking a moment to acknowledge their fear and provide reassurance builds trust and improves outcomes.

triggers.name: Rapid Atrial Fibrillation
triggers.message: Doctor, Mr. Morrison's heart rate just jumped to 142 and it's irregular - looks like rapid A-fib on the monitor. He's feeling his heart racing and he's more short of breath. BP is 138/88. I've got an EKG running. His CHA2DS2-VASc score is going to be high with his history - should I go ahead and get a heparin drip started for stroke prevention? I want to make sure we get that going if you want it. What are your orders?

decisionPoint.name: Anticoagulation Decision
decisionPoint.description: Patient with A-fib and high stroke risk - but has recent major GI bleed making anticoagulation contraindicated
decisionPoint.teachingPoint: Always review a patient's bleeding history before initiating anticoagulation. This patient had a major upper GI bleed 5 months ago with GI recommending against anticoagulation due to high rebleed risk.

triggers.name: Critical Hypoxia
triggers.message: Patient's oxygen saturation has dropped to critical levels. Respiratory is being called.

triggers.name: Severe Fluid Overload
triggers.message: Patient appears significantly more volume overloaded. Having increased difficulty breathing.

triggers.name: Acute Kidney Injury Worsening
triggers.message: Creatinine continues to rise. Nephrology may need to be consulted.

triggers.name: Hyperkalemia Alert
triggers.message: Potassium level is critically elevated. ECG changes may be present.

triggers.name: Hypokalemia Alert
triggers.message: Potassium level is low after diuresis. May need replacement.

triggers.name: Hypotension
triggers.message: Blood pressure has dropped significantly. Patient feeling lightheaded.

triggers.name: Bradycardia
triggers.message: Heart rate has dropped below 55. Please assess need to hold beta-blocker.

triggers.name: Good Diuresis Response
triggers.message: Patient has had good urine output. Weight down significantly. Symptoms improving.

expectedInterventions.name: IV Furosemide
expectedInterventions.rationale: First-line treatment for acute decompensated heart failure

expectedInterventions.name: Hold nephrotoxic medications
expectedInterventions.rationale: Protect renal function during acute illness
